pageTitle: FAQ about Swedish Mauser m/1896, m/1938, Carbine m/1894 and the Ljungman Ag m/42
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {40293=1895-1933, 987=A: It was used to attach the blank firing device. It is normally found on m/1938 and rarely on m/1896. It is never found on the sniper-version m/1941 or the carbine m/1894., 42085=1942-1944, 26191=Yes, there was a special sniper rifle version of the m/96 designated rifle m/41 ("Gevär m/41"). These rifles were selected species of "well shooting" m/96’s. Prior to the modifications their bores were checked and the rifles were fired for accuracy. The modifications consisted of drilling and tapping the receiver on the left side of the receiver and to mount a telescopic sight with mount. These sniper rifles are now obsolete, and were replaced in 1991 with the modern 7,62 mm sniper rifle PSG 90., 43941=1941-1943, 40872=1896-1899, 41481=1899-1936, 39686=1894-1896, 42694=1938-1940, 38053=Production figures for the Swedish Army Rifles m/1896, m/1938, m/1941 and Carbine m/1894.}
textBeforeTable: Production figures for the Swedish Army Rifles m/1896, m/1938, m/1941 and Carbine m/1894.   Mechanism of Long rifle m/96 Mechanism of Long rifle m/96 and Short rifle m/38 type 1 Mechanism of Short rifle m/38 type 2 Mechanism of Carbine m/94 Bolt handles on Kar m/94, Rifle m/96 and m/38.   It was used during rests when the soldiers connected their rifles together with a cleaning rod through this hole.
